Since then, numerous studies have confirmed that fluoridated water helps to strengthen tooth enamel and reduce the risk of cavities.

In the United States, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has called water fluoridation one of the 10 greatest public health achievements of the 20th century. The American Dental Association (ADA), the World Health Organization (WHO), and many other health organizations also support fluoridation.

However, some people have raised concerns about the safety of fluoride in drinking water. They argue that too much fluoride can cause health problems, such as bone fractures, thyroid issues, and even cancer. These concerns have led some communities to stop fluoridating their water.

The scientific consensus is that fluoridated water is safe and effective at preventing tooth decay when used at the recommended levels (usually around 0.7 parts per million). The CDC, ADA, and other health organizations have extensively reviewed the research on fluoride and concluded that the benefits outweigh the risks.

That being said, it's important to acknowledge that there is some debate about the optimal level of fluoride in drinking water. Some studies have suggested that lower levels of fluoride may be just as effective at preventing cavities, while reducing the risk of potential side effects.

In summary, the evidence strongly supports the safety and effectiveness of fluoridated drinking water at recommended levels. However, it's important for individuals to have access to accurate information about the potential risks and benefits of fluoride so they can make informed decisions about their health.
